ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got better at reading primary source ancient Greek texts (especially sight reading), recognizing elements of grammar, and improving my vocabulary.
Skills practicing reading Ancient Greek; skills and practice with sight-reading; how to approach Greek texts, relying on learned grammar and syntax to help understand an unknown sentence

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this is a good course overall. The one weakness was that sometimes we went a little slowly through the texts.
Straightforward and clear expectations, clear course objectives and trajectory with the texts chosen

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you enjoy the language.
A necessary course as a bridge between introductory grammar courses and more advanced Greek reading - definitely would recommend
